tion, and distribution costs plus a small grant to the NAEB. There was con¬
siderable discussion as to the details of the motion, Probst again stated
his feeling that the important thing was the strategic position this would
place us in with the FAE, Harley indicated that any negotiations with the
Iron and Steel Institute might be quite difficult. For instance, the writers
by contract retained the rights to their scripts. Siegel thought that in the
future vie should have all rights to all scripts we pay for. Harley stated
that the standard Radio Writers’ Guild contracts had been used and that this
arrangement was forbidden by these contracts. Someone added that Wishengrad
was one of the leaders of the Guild. Probst argued that we were providing
expensive consultants for the writers and we should have full rights to the
scripts. Wheatley thought that we should have legal counsel in this matter.
Wheatley went on to say that he felt we should recover all production costs
on the Jefferson series from the Iron and Steel Institute. This money should
then be put in a revolving fund to produce more shows. Probst strongly agreed
with this principle. Siegel thought the idea of recovering the funds was all
right, but felt that this committee did not have the right to tie up the money
for production of more shows. Siegel said that the money should be given to
the NAEB and that the NAEB Board should appropriate it for whatever use it
desired. He went on to say that he felt the Board would appropriate it to
do more shows, but that it should have that right. Probst said that it would
be unethical, and certainly unacceptable to Mr. Fletcher and the FAE, if in¬
come from the sale of these radio programs were to be diverted in any way or
any part from the revolving production fund principle. Siegel disagreed,
saying that this matter was not the responsibility of the Adult Education
Committee to decide. Probst pointed out that the Adult Education Committee
had been authorized to administer the Lowell project by both the NAEB and the
FAE. Siegel asked Probst who would administer the fund if the money were col¬
lected and put in a revolving fund. Probst replied that the Adult Education
Committee was responsible for the first year of the grant. Siegel pointed out
that the committee had asked to be relieved of its responsibility in future
years. Probst agreed, but said that if money were collected from the sale of
shows produced under this grant, this committee had the responsibility of
setting up the principle of a revolving fund and expending such funds in the
first year (perhaps to supply enough money to insure production of a full
total of 13 Jefferson shows during May-June), or of leaving the money and
the principle of the revolving fund as a legacy to whoever is responsible for
the second year’s operation. Probst told Siegel that he (Probst) felt he had
been badly burned on the collecting and spending of the ad hoc JCET funds.
Probst said he had been responsible for raising most of the money, and he was
disgusted with the way Siegel tried to convert it to NAEB purposes when the
money had been raised'as a result of the appeal in behalf of the JCET. Siegel
repudiated this imputation. Probst said he was shocked that Siegel would for
a moment consider the possibility that the NAEB Board could exercise the option
of taking these possible Iron and Steel Institute funds for general use by the
NAEB. Such action would destroy the confidence in our project and actions
that had been created in the FAE. Probst said that he would not permit himself
to be associated in any way with such a development. Further, Probst thought
that this matter should not be referred to the NAEB Board at all, for the Board
is not sufficiently informed about the obligations to and understandings with
the FAE to be certain of making & correct decision if given the choice of
